turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: I've remembered something else...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Furtwängler sent Hitler a telegram for his birthday.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: One of your people told me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: One of my people?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Yes. A corporal. US Army. A Jew. He said he'd seen the telegram in the Chancellery.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Son-of-a-gun. We'll find the corporal and we'll find the telegram.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: But I need documentary proof. You know of anything like that?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: No. But that's why we hated him. We admired him as a conductor but we all hated him too because he didn't have to join the Party and yet he had a better life than any of us. He didn't have to go and deliver a report after every trip abroad. He got everything from them, everything. He was filthier than any of us Party members.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: There's a rumour... I don't know if it's true or not... but ask him about von der Null.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Never heard of him, who is he?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Edwin von der Null. Music critic. He gave Furtwängler terrible reviews while he raved about Herbert von Karajan.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Who's he?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Also a conductor. Very brilliant. Young. Von der Null called him 'The Miracle von Karajan'. Furtwängler was outraged and they say he had von der Null conscripted into the army. The same thing happened to another critic. True or not, it's not such a bad idea. Critics give you bad reviews, you have them sent to the Russian front.  But if you really want to get Furtwängler, ask him about Herbert von Karajan.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: The Miracle Kid.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Yes, yes you may notice that he cannot even bring himself to utter his name, he... he refers to him as K.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: And ask him about his private life.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: His private life?

turns.speaker: SCHLEE
turns.text: Goebbels, yes, Josef Goebbels said, 'There's not a single filthy Jew left in Germany on whose behalf Dr. Furtwängler has not intervened.' No, no one could have been less of a Nazi than Dr. Furtwängler.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: But this was the same guy who conducted for Adolf on his birthday.

turns.speaker: SCHLEE
turns.text: He was forced to do that. But he refused to give the Nazi salute in front of Hitler. He kept his baton in his hand, you can't salute with a baton in your hand.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Oh! The evening before, I see...

turns.speaker: SCHLEE
turns.text: Yes, Dr. Furtwängler was absolutely clear about this: politics and art must be kept separate.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Politics and art must be kept separate. I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand. I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You ever seen Adolf Hitler's eyes when he was making a speech? I've seen 'em on films.

turns.speaker: SCHLEE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Was looking at Furtwängler like that?

turns.speaker: SCHLEE
turns.text: I don't know what you mean, Major.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: When you got to the crescendo.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: So, you never heard of him.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Do you know who Arturo Toscanini is?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: He's as big as Toscanini, maybe even bigger. In this neck of the woods, he's probably Bob Hope and Betty Grable rolled into one.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Jeez, and I never heard of him.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: You were in insurance before the war.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Right. Claims assessor.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Conscientious, determined, dogged.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: They said I was dogged?

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Well, they say here that when you went on a case, you stayed on it.  Now we can't take every Nazi in this country to trial, although I would like to; it's an impossibility. So we're going for the big boys in industry, education, law, culture.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Like this bandleader.

turns.speaker: WALLACE
turns.text: Well, he's more than just a bandleader, Steve. He's a great conductor, a gifted artist. But we believe that he sold himself to the devil. Your number one priority from this moment on is to connect him to the Nazi Party. Don't be impressed by him. I want the folks back home to understand why we fought this war. Find Wilhelm Furtwängler guilty. He represents everything that was rotten in Germany.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Rudolf Otto Werner. Wind section since 1936. What instrument did you play?

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: First oboe.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I have your questionnaire here. It says you were never a member of the Nazi Party.

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: Absolutely not.

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: No, I was never a Nazi, I have no interest in politics, I'm a musician -

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Hey, hey, slow up, Fraulein Straube has to take down what you say.

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: Dr. Furtwängler is a great musician. He actively opposed the Nazis and later on he helped many Jews to escape.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Then how do you explain him being made a Prussian Privy Councillor?

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: It was Hermann Goering. I was told he just made the maestro his Privy Councillor, no questions asked. Although Dr. Furtwängler stood up to him. And to Dr. Goebbels.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: He also conducted for Hitler, didn't he?

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: Yes, that's true, but he refused to give the Nazi salute. He kept his baton in his right hand. In Hitler's presence. That was a brave act...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Brave?  To celebrate Hitler's birthday with some heroic piece by Wagner but without the Nazi salute? Bravo.

turns.speaker: WERNER
turns.text: It was Beethoven's Ninth.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do you really think it was brave? Didn't he bow to him and shake his hand?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes, Chuck?

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: Come to the office, please.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Mission control to Chuck, come in...

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: You're late.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Aren't I worth waiting for?

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: Not really.  Do you think you can get here on time if I put you on the floor as a waitress?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I don't know.  I kinda had my heart set on being a cashier the rest of my life.

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: The pay's the same but you'll make more in tips.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Thanks, Chuck.  I need the money.  Can I still work the hours around my classes?

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: Mmm.  Same schedule's okay.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Alright!

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: Can you handle it?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It's not brain surgery, Chuck.

turns.speaker: BREEN
turns.text: Here you go.  You're a Bob's Girl now.  Nancy will check you out.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I won't let the fat kid down.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Anything else?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: A phased plasma pulse-laser in the forty watt range...

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Just what you see, pal.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: The Uzi 9 millimeter.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: You know your weapons, buddy.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Any one of them's ideal for home defense. Which'll it be?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: All.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: You can't to that...

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Wrong.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I had him hooked.  He was just about to ask me out. I could tell.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: That guy's a jerk.  I did you a favor.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'll do the same for you sometime.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You're a big help.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Alright, the beige one.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I hate the beige one.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Don't wear the beige one.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: Not lately.  Did you check messages?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I thought you did.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: That bum.  So what if he has a Porsche, he can't treat you like that...it's Friday night for crissakes.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm going to a movie, kiddo. See ya'.  You and Matt have a good time.

turns.speaker: GINGER
turns.text: We will, kiddo.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I haven't seen you in here lately, Mr. Miller.

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: What's it to ya?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You must have a girlfriend.

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: That's none of your business.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Aha!  Is she young?

turns.speaker: MR. MILLER
turns.text: Compared to me she is.  How come you're not at the cash anymore?  They catch ya steal- ing?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What's it to ya?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Do you understand?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes.  Don't hurt me.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I'm here to help you.  Reese, Sergeant/Tech-Com, DN38416...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: This is a mistake.  I haven't done anything.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: No. But you will.  It's very important that you live.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: But outside, it's living human tissue.  Flesh, skin, hair...blood.  Grown for the cyborgs.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Look, Reese, I know you want to help, but...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Pay attention.  The 600 series had rubber skin. We spotted them easy.  But these are new.  They look human.  Sweat, bad breath, everything.  Very hard to spot.  I had to wait 'til he moved on you before I could zero him.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Hey, I'm not stupid, y'know. They can't build anything like that yet.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: No.  Not yet.  Not for about forty years.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: So, it's from the future, is that right?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: One possible future.  Four your point of view.  I don't know the tech stuff.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: And you're from the future too?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Just let me go.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Listen.  Understand.  That Terminator is out there.  It can't be reasoned with, it can't be bargained with...it doesn't feel pity of remorse or fear... and it absolutely will not stop. Ever.  Until you are dead.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: There's so much...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Tell me.  Just start at the beginning.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: --everythingis gone.  Just gone.  There were survivors. Here.  There.  Nobody knew who started it.  It was the machines.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I don't understand...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Defense network computer. New. Powerful.  Hooked into everything. Trusted to run it all.  They say it got smart...a new order of intelli- gence.  Then it saw all people as a threat, not just the ones on the other side.  Decided out fate in a microsecond...extermination.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Didn't see the war.  I was born after, in the ruins.  Grew up there.  Starving.  Hiding from the H-K's.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Hunter Killers.  Patrol machines. Build in automated factories. Most of us were rounded up, put in camps...for orderly disposal.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: You cold?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Freezing.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Reese...you got a first name?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Kyle.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Kyle, what's it like when you go through time?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: White light.  Pain.  Like being ripped inside out... slowly.  Like being born, maybe.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I caught one, back there.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Caught one?  You mean you got shot?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: We gotta get you to a doctor.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: It's okay.  Forget it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Forget it?  Are you crazy? Let me see it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: This is gonna make me puke. Talk about something.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Just talk.  Tell me about my son.  Is he tall?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What's he like?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: You trust him.  He's got that strength.  You'd die in a second for John.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Well, at least I know what to name him.  I don't suppose you'd know who the father is? So I don't tell him to get lost when I meet him.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: John never said much about him.  He dies.  Even before the war...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Stop!  I don't want to know. Hold still.  So...it was John that ordered you here?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I volunteered.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You volunteered?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: It was an honor.  A chance to meet the legend.  Sarah Connor.  Who taught her son to fight...organize, prepare. From when he was a kid.  When you were in hiding, before the war.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Come on, me? The mother of the future?  Am I tough? Organized?  I can't even balance my checkbook.  I cry when I see a cat that's been run over... and I don't even like cats.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Ow!  No, it's okay.  It's better tight.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: And anyway, what do I know about guerrilla warfare?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: You'll learn.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Look, Reese, I didn't ask for this honor and I don't want it. Any of it.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: John gave me a message for you.  Made me memorize it. 'Sarah"...this is the message... 'Sarah, thank you.  For your courage through the dark years. I can't help you with what you must soon face, except to tell you that the future is not set... there is no such thing as Fate, but what we make for ourselves by our own will.  You must be stronger than you imagine you can be.  You must survive, or I will never exist.'  That's all.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Good field-dressing.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You like it?  It's my first.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Sleep.  It'll be light soon.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Okay.  Talk some more.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: About where you're from.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Bag some Z's?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Let's get cleaned up, Kyle.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That's where we're going.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Look.  I found it.  Isn't that it?  Cyber Dynamics Corporation?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Didn't you say that they're going to develop this revolutionary new thing...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Molecular-memory.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Whatever...they become the hotshot computer guys so they get the job to build El Computer Grande...Skynet...for the government.  Right?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: That's the way it was told to me.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Well, we're gonna uninvent the bastard.  Eighty-six it.  We'll blow up the place...burn it down.  Something.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Tactically dangerous.  We lay low.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Reese.  Think it through. We can prevent the war. Nobody else is gonna do it. If we go to anybody official we wind up back in jail and then that walking cuisinart has got us again.  We have to so it ourselves.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: That's not my mission.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Listen.  Understand.  I'm not a military objective, Reese.  I'm a person... You don't own me.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Let's go.  Time to move out.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Fuck you!  Let go of me!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Kyle?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I'm wrong here.  I wasn't meant to see this...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Is this enough?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes.  And I don't want to know where you got it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'm dying for a shower.  You could use one too.  And we'd better check that bandage.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Later.  I'm going out for materiel.  Keep this.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Nitroglycerin, basically. Bit more stable.  I learned howto make it when I was a kid.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Make sure there's none on the threads, like this.  Now screw the end-cap on...very gently.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You must have had a fun child-

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: That's good.  Now, seven more like that while I make fuses.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I was thinking, there's so much I've got to show you when we get through this. It's mind boggling, the pos- sibilities...Disneyland, the beach, movies...matinees with popcorn and foot-long hot dogs...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Hot dogs?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I want to buy you a hot dog so bad,Kyle...all the things you've never seen and done.  You're here, but wherever you go, and whatever you touch, you bring the war with you.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: My whole life has been combat.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I want it to be over for you.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Not possible.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I want it to be over for me too. I feel like I slipped over some invisible line, that I'm in your world now.  Everything's the same, but I see it differently. It's like, there's you and me, and him...but nobody else can understand or help or even touch us.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: He'll find us, won't he?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Probably.  Sarah, if I get zeroed...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Don't say that.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: If I do, you have to get away, disappear without a trace. Different country, different name, everything.  In case they send another one.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It'll never be over, will it? Look at me, I'm shaking. Some legend, huh?  You must be pretty disappointed.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: No.  I'm not.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Kyle, the women in your time...what were they like?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Good fighters.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That's not what I meant. Was there someone special?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Someone?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: A girl.  You know.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: No.  Never.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: So much pain.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Pain can be controlled. You disconnect it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: And so you feel nothing.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: It's better that way.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh, Kyle.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I shouldn't have said...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Kyle...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I bet you're ticklish.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Ticklish?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You'll beg for mercy in a second.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I don't think I like this.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You're not supposed to.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Sarah.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: We did it, Kyle.  We got it.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Cover...our footsteps...

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: So.  You're a soldier. Fighting for whom?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: With the One Thirty Second under Perry, from '21 to '27--

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: The year 2027?

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: And who was the enemy?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: SKYNET.  A computer defense system built for SAC-NORAD by Cyber Dynamics.  A modified Series 4800.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: I see.  And this...computer, thinks it can win by killing the mother of its enemy, kill- ing him, in effect, before he is even conceived?  A sort of retroactive abortion?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: ...it had no choice. The defensive grid was smashed. We'd taken the mainframes... We'd won.  Taking out Connor then would make no difference.  Skynet had to wipe out his entire exist- ence.  We captured the lab complex.  Found the...what- ever it was called...the time-displacement equipment. The Terminator had already gone through.  They sent two of us to intercept, then zeroed the whole place. Sumner didn't make it.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: Then how are you supposed to get back?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Can't.  Nobody goes home. Nobody else comes through. It's just him and me.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: You go naked.  Something about the field generated by a living organism.  Nothing dead will go.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I didn't build the fucking thing.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: Okay.  Okay.  But this...  cyborg...if it's metal...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Surrounded by living tissue.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: Why were the other two women killed?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Most official records were lost in the war.  The computer knew almost nothing about Connor's mother.  Her name. Where she lived, just the city. No scanner pictures.  The Terminator was just being systematic.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: You've heard enough.  Decide. Are you going to release me?

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: I'm afraid that's not up to me.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Then why am I talking to you? Get out.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: I can help you...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Who is in authority here?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: ...look, Lieutenant...uh, Vukovich, don't put me on hold and don't transfer me to another department...

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: I won't.  Now just relax. Where are you?  Yeah, I know it...on Pico. Are you alright?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yes, but I don't want to leave.  I think this guy's following me.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Alright, Ms. Connor.  Listen carefully.  You're in a public place, you'll be safe 'til we get there.  Stay visible. Don't go outside or in the restroom.  I'll be there in a few minutes.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Here, drink some of this...

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Lieutenant, are you sure it's them?  Maybe I should see the ...bodies.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: They've already been identi- fied.  There's no doubt.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Sarah.  Sarah, this is Dr. Silber- man.  I'd like you to tell him everything Reese said to you.  Do you feel up to it?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I guess so.  You're a doctor?

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Why don't you just stretch out here and get some sleep.  It'll take your mom a good hour to get here from Redlands.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I can't sleep.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Go ahead.  You're safe.  There're thirty cops in this building.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Give me the short version.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Six shots at less than ten feet.  Weapon was a large caliber--

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Okay, let's see...Got a pos- itive on her.  She's Sarah Connor, works as a legal--

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: That can't be right.  That's the name of the one Valley Division mopped up this after- noon.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Here's her driver's license.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: You gotta be kidding me.  The new guys'll be short-stroking it over this one.  A one-day pattern killer.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: I hate the weird ones.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: That stuff's two hours cold.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: I put a cigarette out in it.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Did you reach the next girl yet?

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: No.  Keep getting an answer- ing machine.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Send a unit.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: I already did.  No answer at the door and the apartment manager's out.  I'm keeping them there.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Call her.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: I just called.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Call her again.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Same shit.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: I can hear it now, it's gonna be the goddamned 'Phone Book Killer'.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: I hate the press cases. Especially the weird press cases.  Where you going?

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: To make a statement. I'm gonna give them the name.  Maybe the jackals can help us out for once.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: If they can get this on the tube by eleven, she may just call us.  How do I look?

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Like shit, boss.

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Go!  Go!  He's got her.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Suspect westbound on Olympic.  Grey sedan.  Has hostage, repeat...

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: That Silberman just crack me up.  He had this guy in here last week who set his Afghan on fire. Screwed it first, then set it on--

turns.speaker: VUKOVICH
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: You promised you'd meet projections, Alan.  A dollar sixty per share you said.  So, I don't think this is so surprising a visit.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Projections were far too optimistic.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: Admittedly...

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Our E.P.S. was one fifty last quarter.  We're up eight cents per share.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: But, the expectation was ten.  And, in this case, expectation is everything.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Will you really hold me to it over <u>pennies</u>?

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: My stock's falling.  Isn't yours? Those pennies are costing me millions.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: The stock will turn.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: It probably will.  In fact, I'd go so far as to say it almost certainly will, in time.  Why should I settle for that?

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Because it's fair.  Give me next quarter.  If you still feel this way, vote your shares...

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: You're talking tomorrow.  Today is what counts.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: You intractable son-of-a-bitch.  If your father could see you now...

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Your father was a friend.  Goddamn it... I watched you grow up.  How do you end up treating me like this?

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: It is so very inappropriate for you to mention my father.  Or, did you think this, between us, was friendship?  Just because you went fishing with my father, I should sit on my hands while you throw my money away?

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Now, look...

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: I'll be done in a minute.  You misspoke before.  You're not "stepping down."  I'm taking you out at the knees.  The whole point is to prove that you're not deciding anything anymore.  I'm firing you. Action's taken.  Confidence restored. Stock goes up.  I sell my shares.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: There is no Baer/Grant Publishing without Alan Baer.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: Remember Daniel Grant?  Do they say, "without Daniel Grant, there is no Baer/Grant Publishing?"  He's gone sailing, Alan.  He's out there enjoying his golden years, probably wondering where you are.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: I could fight you on this.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: You could.  But, if I leave without your signature, this agreement begins to disintegrate; benefits shrink, options narrow, compensations shrivel.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: Are you finished?

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: No.  This is my lawyer, Samuel Sutherland.  I thought you two should meet.

turns.speaker: ALAN BAER
turns.text: We met, this morning.  I signed the termination contract for Baer/Grace. I accepted your settlement, Nicholas. you were right.  I'm going sailing.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: I only mention it because I took the test this afternoon, down on Montgomery Street.

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 2
turns.text: Did you?  Kudos.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: Did you play recently?

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 2
turns.text: Hm?  No, about a year ago.  I was working out of Los Angeles.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: I've heard good things about their London branch.  You have to admit, it sounds like some fantasy, role-playing nonsense.

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 2
turns.text: You want to know what it is?  What it's all about?  John.  Chapter nine.  Verse twenty-five.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: I, uh... haven't been to Sunday school in years...

turns.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 2
turns.text: "Whereas once I was blind, now I can see."  Night, Nick.  Best of luck.

turns.speaker: MAITRE D'
turns.text: Christine!   Mister Van Orton is a valued customer...

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: Then, you kiss his ass.

turns.speaker: MAITRE D'
turns.text: You don't talk to me like that.

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: I apologized, I offered to help.

turns.speaker: MAITRE D'
turns.text: Clean out your locker.

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: Fine, Dennis.  Soon as I get my money for this week.

turns.speaker: MAITRE D'
turns.text: I'll be right with you.

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: I'm so sorry.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: Please, don't do that...

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: I apologize, sir, I'm having a bad day...

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: A bad month.  You did the exact same thing to me last week.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: Don't help me, just get more napkins. And soda water.

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: It was an accident.

turns.speaker: NICHOLAS
turns.text: Terrific.  I now have a hundred dollar dry cleaning bill.

turns.speaker: CHRISTINE
turns.text: I said I was sorry...
